xxl.core.collections.containers.io

Class BufferedContainer

  • java.lang.Object
    • xxl.core.collections.containers.AbstractContainer
      • xxl.core.collections.containers.ConstrainedDecoratorContainer
        • xxl.core.collections.containers.io.BufferedContainer
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Container

    public class BufferedContainer
extends ConstrainedDecoratorContainer
    This class wraps a container by buffering its elements in a given buffer. There are only little differences between the buffered container and the wrapped container:
    every time elements of the buffered container are accessed, the buffer is check first, whether it contains the desired elements. When the desired elements are not buffered, the elements are taken from the wrapped container.

    Example usage (1). 

         // create a new buffered container with ...

     BufferedContainer container = new BufferedContainer(

         // a map container that stores the elements

         new MapContainer(),

         // a LRU buffer with 5 slots

         new LRUBuffer(5)
     );

     // create an iteration over 20 random Integers (between 0 and 100)

     Iterator iterator = new Enumerator(20);

     // insert all elements of the given iterator

     iterator = container.insertAll(iterator);

     // print all elements of the queue

     while (iterator.hasNext())
         System.out.println(container.get(iterator.next()));

     // get the ids of the elements of the container

     iterator = container.ids();

     // remove 5 elements

     for (int i = 0; i < 5 && iterator.hasNext(); i++) {
         container.remove(iterator.next());

         // refresh the iterator (cause it can be in an invalid state)

         iterator = container.ids();
     }

     // fix 5 elements in the buffer

     for (int i = 0; i < 5 && iterator.hasNext(); i++)
         container.get(iterator.next(), false);

     // try to access another element (the buffer will overrun)

     try {
         container.get(iterator.next());
     }
     catch (Exception e) {
         System.out.println(e);
     }

     // flushes the whole buffer

     container.flush();

     // get the ids of the elements of the container

     iterator = container.ids();

     // print all elements of the queue

     while (iterator.hasNext())
         System.out.println(container.get(iterator.next()));

     // close the open queue after use

     container.close();
    See Also:
    Constant, Container, ConstrainedDecoratorContainer, Function, Iterator, NoSuchElementException

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      protected Buffer buffer
      The buffer that is used for buffering the elements of the container.
      protected boolean cloneObjects
      Flag which determines if every object is cloned before storing and before returning it.
      protected boolean writeBack
      A flag that determines whether the buffered elements should be written back to the container, when they are flushed (true) or if they already should be written back after each update operation (false).

    • Constructor Detail

      • BufferedContainer

        public BufferedContainer(Container container,
                         Buffer buffer,
                         boolean writeBack,
                         boolean cloneObjects)
        Constructs a new buffered container that uses the specified buffer for buffering the elements of the given container. The flag writeBack determines whether the buffered elements should be written back to the container, when they are flushed (true) or if they already should be written back after each update operation (false).
        Parameters:
        container - the container to be buffered.
        buffer - the buffer used for buffering the specified container.
        writeBack - Signals that the buffered elements should be written back to the container, when they are flushed (true) or if they already should be written back after each update operation (false). Use writeBack with care. The inserted/updated object must stay unchanged until the buffer writes back the object to the underlying container.
        cloneObjects - determines if every object is cloned before storing and before returning it. The clone mode is a lot slower, because reflection is needed to call the protected clone Method.

      • BufferedContainer

        public BufferedContainer(Container container,
                         Buffer buffer,
                         boolean writeBack)
        Constructs a new buffered container that uses the specified buffer for buffering the elements of the given container. The flag writeBack determines whether the buffered elements should be written back to the container, when they are flushed (true) or if they already should be written back after each update operation (false).
        Parameters:
        container - the container to be buffered.
        buffer - the buffer used for buffering the specified container.
        writeBack - Signals that the buffered elements should be written back to the container, when they are flushed (true) or if they already should be written back after each update operation (false). Use writeBack with care. The inserted/updated object must stay unchanged until the buffer writes back the object to the underlying container.

      • BufferedContainer

        public BufferedContainer(Container container,
                         Buffer buffer)
        Constructs a new buffered container that uses the specified buffer for buffering the elements of the given container. When flushing a buffered element, it will be written back to the container. This constructor is equivalent to the call of BufferedContainer(container, buffer, true). Look at the remarks for writeBack!
        Parameters:
        container - the container to be buffered.
        buffer - the buffer used for buffering the specified container.

    • Method Detail

      • clear

        public void clear()
        Removes all elements from the container. After a call of this method, size() will return 0.
        This implementation removes all buffered elements out of the buffer and clears the wrapped container thereafter.
        Specified by:
        clear in interface Container
        Overrides:
        clear in class ConstrainedDecoratorContainer

      • close

        public void close()
        Closes the Container and releases all sources. For external containers, this method closes the files immediately. MOREOVER, all iterators operating on the container can be in illegal states. Close can be called a second time without any impact.
        This implementation flushes all buffered elements and removes them out of the buffer. Thereafter the wrapped container is closed.
        Specified by:
        close in interface Container
        Overrides:
        close in class ConstrainedDecoratorContainer

      • contains

        public boolean contains(Object id)
        Returns true if the container contains an object for the identifier id.
        First, this implementation checks the buffer, if it contains an object for id. Thereafter the wrapped container is checked.
        Specified by:
        contains in interface Container
        Overrides:
        contains in class ConstrainedDecoratorContainer
        Parameters:
        id - identifier of the object.
        Returns:
        true if the container contains an object for the specified identifier.

      • flush

        public void flush()
        Flushes all modified elements from the buffer into the container. After this call the buffer and the container are synchronized.
        This implementation flushes all buffered elements first. Thereafter the elements of the wrapped container are flushed (in order to support a second buffer etc.).
        Specified by:
        flush in interface Container
        Overrides:
        flush in class ConstrainedDecoratorContainer

      • flush

        public void flush(Object id)
        Flushes the object with identifier id from the buffer into the container.
        This implementation flushes the buffered element with the given id first. Thereafter the element of the wrapped container is flushed (in order to support a second buffer etc.).
        Specified by:
        flush in interface Container
        Overrides:
        flush in class ConstrainedDecoratorContainer
        Parameters:
        id - identifier of the object that should be written back.

      • get

        public Object get(Object id,
                  boolean unfix)
           throws NoSuchElementException
        Returns the object associated to the identifier id. An exception is thrown when the desired object is not found. If unfix, the object can be removed from the underlying buffer. Otherwise (!unfix), the object has to be kept in the buffer.
        This implementation calls the get method of the buffer with a function that returns the desired object of the container, when it is invoked.
        Specified by:
        get in interface Container
        Overrides:
        get in class ConstrainedDecoratorContainer
        Parameters:
        id - identifier of the object.
        unfix - signals whether the object can be removed from the underlying buffer.
        Returns:
        the object associated to the specified identifier.
        Throws:
        NoSuchElementException - if the desired object is not found.

      • ids

        public Iterator ids()
        Returns an iterator that delivers the identifiers of all objects of the container.
        Specified by:
        ids in interface Container
        Overrides:
        ids in class ConstrainedDecoratorContainer
        Returns:
        an iterator of object identifiers.

      • insert

        public Object insert(Object object,
                     boolean unfix)
        Inserts a new object into the container and returns the unique identifier that the container has been associated to the object. If unfixed, the object can be removed from the buffer. Otherwise, it has to be kept in the buffer until an unfix() is called.
        After an insertion all the iterators operating on the container can be in an invalid state.
        This implementation inserts the object into the wrapped container. Thereafter it is inserted into the buffer by calling the buffer's get method.
        Specified by:
        insert in interface Container
        Overrides:
        insert in class ConstrainedDecoratorContainer
        Parameters:
        object - is the new object.
        unfix - signals whether the object can be removed from the underlying buffer.
        Returns:
        the identifier of the object.

      • isUsed

        public boolean isUsed(Object id)
        Checks whether the id has been returned previously by a call to insert or reserve and hasn't been removed so far.
        Specified by:
        isUsed in interface Container
        Overrides:
        isUsed in class ConstrainedDecoratorContainer
        Parameters:
        id - the id to be checked.
        Returns:
        true exactly if the id is still in use.

      • remove

        public void remove(Object id)
            throws NoSuchElementException
        Removes the object with identifier id. An exception is thrown when an object with an identifier id is not in the container.
        After a call of remove() all the iterators (and cursors) can be in an invalid state.
        First, this implementation removes the object from the buffer. Thereafter it is removed from the wrapped container.
        Specified by:
        remove in interface Container
        Overrides:
        remove in class ConstrainedDecoratorContainer
        Parameters:
        id - an identifier of an object.
        Throws:
        NoSuchElementException - if an object with an identifier id is not in the container.

      • unfix

        public void unfix(Object id)
           throws NoSuchElementException
        Unfixes the object with identifier id. This method throws an exception when no element with an identifier id is in the container. After one call of unfix the buffer is allowed to remove the object (although the objects have been fixed more than once).
        This implementation unfixes the buffered object first. Thereafter the object of the wrapped container is unfixed (in order to support a second buffer etc.).
        Specified by:
        unfix in interface Container
        Overrides:
        unfix in class ConstrainedDecoratorContainer
        Parameters:
        id - identifier of an object that should be unfixed in the buffer.
        Throws:
        NoSuchElementException - if no element with an identifier id is in the container.

      • update

        public void update(Object id,
                   Object object,
                   boolean unfix)
            throws NoSuchElementException
        Overwrites an existing (id,*)-element by (id, object). This method throws an exception if an object with an identifier id does not exist in the container.
        This implementation calls update method of the buffer. When the buffered elements should be written back to the buffer, the update method is called with a flush function, that updates the element of the wrapped container with the buffered element. Otherwise, the element of the wrapped container is updated once after calling the buffer's update method.
        Specified by:
        update in interface Container
        Overrides:
        update in class ConstrainedDecoratorContainer
        Parameters:
        id - identifier of the element.
        object - the new object that should be associated to id.
        unfix - signals whether the object can be removed from the underlying buffer.
        Throws:
        NoSuchElementException - if an object with an identifier id does not exist in the container.

      • fixedElements

        public int fixedElements()
        Returns the number of fixed elements in the container's buffer.
